Notes: The absolute hegemon of UK tax filing. It manages the "case" of a client's accounts production. Desktop-heavy, incredibly expensive, and hated for its price hikes, but holds the tax logic that practitioners fear to leave.

The "SAP" of car dealerships. It manages the "case" of a vehicle from sales to service history. Formerly CDK International. Deeply integrated into the parts supply chain, making it nearly impossible to rip out.
The operating system for 58% of UK GPs. It holds the "case" of a patient's entire medical history. Clinical safety rules make this the highest barrier-to-entry market in the UK.
The idiosyncratic rival to EMIS. Used by GPs and community hospitals. Famous for its "one database" architecture. The interface is utilitarian and dates back to the early 2000s.
The other half of the duopoly with Civica. Formerly Northgate Public Services. Manages council house waiting lists and benefits. It is the definition of "too big to fail" legacy infrastructure.
The global standard for real estate investment trusts (REITs). It manages the "case" of a commercial lease and the asset valuation. Incredibly complex accounting logic for multi-currency funds.
The Microsoft-based challenger to Keyloop. Gaining ground because it integrates better with modern tech stacks, but still a heavy ERP for car dealers. Recently spun out of Pendragon.
Aggressive Australian entrant that conquered the high street. Replaces server-based legacy systems. It forces firms to use its specific way of working. Very "sticky" due to content libraries.
The direct rival to Liquidlogic. Used by Councils to manage child protection cases. Recently acquired by Access Group to bolster their health/gov division. Statutory reporting is the moat.
"JobWatch" system for companies with vans. It manages the "case" of a job from quote to invoice.[1] Replaces paper diaries. Very growth-focused and tablet-first.
Manages the "case" of a new tenant moving in (referencing, contracts, payments). It sits between the estate agent and the tenant. Replaces the fragmented email chain of signing a lease.
ERP for building firms. Manages the "case" of a construction project (job costing, CIS tax deduction). Deep integration with Sage accounts makes it the default for mid-sized builders.
Zoopla's cloud answer to the legacy "Vebra" systems. It manages the "case" of a property sale. Being cloud-native is its selling point, but migration from desktop systems is slow.
The cloud-native disruption to SIMS. Manages student attendance and behavior. Growing rapidly because it offers data insights that legacy systems can't match.
The US giant pushing into the UK. Focuses on the "case" workflow for smaller firms. Very polished UI compared to UK legacy players, but struggles with niche UK legal aid rules.
The global rival to Optix. Used by large chains (like Specsavers) and independents. Manages the clinical eye test and the retail sale of frames. High barrier due to medical device integration.
Focuses purely on the "case" of a broken boiler. Tenants report issues via pictures. It integrates with the big property CRMs (Reapit/Alto) rather than replacing them.
The "Operating System" for recruitment. It handles the "case" of a candidate placement. Feature-dense and complex, recently swallowed by the Access Group aggregator.
Built on top of Microsoft Dynamics. Used by larger law firms who want an enterprise-grade platform. It handles the "case" within the familiar Microsoft ecosystem.
Glasgow-based challenger. Focuses on the "marketing" side of the candidate case. Replaces the "black book" with a searchable talent pool. Cult following in SME agencies.
